Contradict fact: The claim that face masks are aimed at protecting the wearer from COVID-19 is contradicted by the statement on the box of masks that says they will not provide any protection against COVID-19.
Understate: The claim may understate the effectiveness of face masks in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The CDC states that face coverings may prevent the spread of the virus from the wearer to others, which suggests that they do offer some level of protection.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it only provides a statement from a box of masks and does not provide any scientific evidence or research to back up the assertion that face masks are aimed at protecting the wearer from COVID-19.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the purpose of face masks is solely to protect the wearer from COVID-19, while the CDC states that their primary purpose is to prevent the spread of the virus from the wearer to others.
Exist alternative explanation: The alternative explanation is provided by the CDC, which states that face coverings can help prevent people who may have the virus and do not know it from transmitting it to others. This suggests that the main aim of face masks is to protect others rather than the wearer.
